This rule, far from being hostile to religions, aims to preserve the freedom of conscience of each child and the equality of all with regard to education. It is imperative to defend and apply this principle throughout the country to maintain the school as a space of cohesion. Thus, this would help prevent community pressures and restore the school as the crucible of French citizenship.

The idea would be to sanctify public schooling as a space of neutrality and emancipation, where republican principles take precedence over any other consideration. The proper approach is to guarantee the strict and uncompromising enforcement of the existing legal framework that prohibits the wearing of ostentatious religious symbols. School must remain a protected place, devoted to the transmission of knowledge and to the education of the citizen, sheltered from communal pressures and identity-based claims. Thus, this would help preserve national cohesion by ensuring that each pupil can build themselves freely, as an individual and citizen, in respect of the common values that underpin the Republic.

The idea would be to safeguard public school as a space of emancipation and neutrality, sheltered from religious and social pressures. The proper approach is to maintain a clear secularism there, which is expressed by prohibiting students from wearing signs or clothing that ostentatiously manifest a religious affiliation. This rule is not intended to stigmatize a belief, but to guarantee everyone's freedom of conscience and to combat symbols of the oppression of women. School must be a protected place where free and equal citizens are formed. Thus, this would make it possible to ensure that each student, and in particular each young girl, has a protected environment in which to build her autonomy.

question: Should France increase its military spending in the current geopolitical context?

propositions.value: The idea would be to break radically with the militaristic and interventionist stance by engaging in an active policy of unilateral disarmament. The proper approach is to undertake the complete dismantling of the military-industrial complex, redirecting its production capacities toward the ecological transition. The central axis is the immediate halt of all arms exports and the withdrawal from all military alliances, notably NATO. This approach must culminate in the destruction of the nuclear arsenal and the end of any external military intervention. Thus, it would free up considerable financial resources for social and ecological emergencies, while grounding international relations in cooperation and solidarity among peoples rather than in military power.

The idea would be to undertake a planned and substantial rearmament, the only possible response to the deterioration of the international environment and the return of power politics. The central axis is to raise the armed forces' budget to 55 billion euros by 2027. This significant financial effort will be earmarked for increasing personnel, modernizing equipment and replenishing ammunition stocks. This build-up in material and human capacity is the condition for guaranteeing the credibility of nuclear deterrence, which remains the cornerstone of national defence. Thus, this would make it possible to provide the country with the means necessary for a genuine "free-hands policy", restoring to it full control over its commitments and the ability to defend its strategic interests in complete independence.

The idea would be to break with a logic of military alignment and an arms race in order to rebuild a defense doctrine focused on national sovereignty and the pursuit of peace. The right approach is to withdraw from the integrated command of OTAN to regain full strategic autonomy, and to refuse any military intervention without an explicit mandate from ONU. Resources should be redirected toward a popular defense, including citizen conscription and the nationalization of the arms industries, rather than fueling an escalation. In this way, it would enable equipping the country with an independent defense in service of a policy of active peace and cooperation, rather than allocating increasing budgets to a logic of blocs and confrontation.

The idea would be to respond to the deterioration of the geopolitical context by restoring the capability and strength of our armed forces. The central axis of this strategy is a massive, planned budgetary effort, resulting in an increase of 108 billion euros in credits allocated to defence by 2030. This exceptional investment aims to equip the forces with all the means necessary to ensure the protection of the territory and of citizens against new threats, as revealed by the invasion of Ukraine. This ambition is part of a national framework of sovereignty and is articulated with the project of a more autonomous European defence. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee the country's security and to reaffirm its status as a leading military power.

The idea would be to reconfigure the military apparatus to guarantee full national sovereignty, by optimizing existing resources rather than increasing overall spending. The priority is to end costly overseas operations and to leave integrated military structures in order to free up budgetary room for maneuver. These savings would then be reinvested in modernizing a versatile and coherent defense capability, focused on protecting the territory and maintaining a national deterrent force. A public hub for the arms industries would also be created to ensure this strategic autonomy. Thus, this would make it possible to build a modern and effective defense, financed by an intelligent reallocation of means, guaranteeing a true strategic independence without committing the country to a new arms race.

The idea would be to break with chronic underinvestment to reverse the downgrading of the defense apparatus and guarantee the country's strategic autonomy. The approach consists of a programmed and massive increase in the armed forces' budget, aiming to reach €70 billion per year by 2030. This financial effort will be earmarked for the modernization of the nuclear deterrent, the rebuilding of conventional capabilities (with targets of two aircraft carriers, twenty frigates and three hundred fighter jets) and investment in new fields of conflict such as cyber and space. Thus, this would make it possible to rebuild a complete and powerful army, a pillar of national sovereignty and capable of ensuring the protection of French interests in the world.

The idea would be to guarantee national sovereignty by rebuilding an autonomous and comprehensive defense, capable of operating outside existing alliances. The central axis is to rebuild a fully sovereign arms and equipment industry, so as no longer to depend on foreign suppliers. This effort must include a major strengthening of cyberdefense, allocating to it a substantial budget equal to one quarter of that of the other armies. In addition, the creation of a Garde Nationale will provide the regular army with an indispensable reserve force. Thus, this would make it possible to have the military means necessary for an independent defense policy and diplomacy, a prerequisite for disengagement from integrated military command structures.

The idea would be to guarantee France's sovereignty and the security of its citizens by adapting its defense capabilities to the challenges of the 21st century. The central axis is an increase in the resources allocated to our armed forces, which will result in an upward revision of the loi de programmation militaire 2019-2025. This budgetary effort will primarily target the strengthening of research and development as well as adaptation to new threats, notably in the space and cybersecurity domains. Thus, this would enable the country to possess a credible and modern defense, capable of protecting the national territory and of facing the evolving geopolitical context.

The idea would be to replace the logic of increasing budgets with an approach of rationalizing and optimizing defense spending. The issue is to guarantee security through better efficiency and active diplomacy, not through an arms race. The right approach is to implement concrete measures of arms control and reduction, while advocating for a concerted reduction of military spending on a global scale. Priority will be given to integrating defense production at the European level and to strengthening cooperation in the prevention and non-violent resolution of conflicts. Thus, this would allow resources to be allocated more fairly and effectively, contributing to global de-escalation rather than to the exacerbation of geopolitical tensions.

The idea would be to guarantee the strategic independence of the nation by rebuilding a defense apparatus commensurate with the geopolitical stakes. The right approach is to ring-fence military spending by raising its budget to 2,5 % of Gross Domestic Product, versus 2 % currently. This financial effort will make it possible to launch a massive recruitment plan aimed at integrating 40 000 additional soldiers over five years, in order to make up for lost personnel. In parallel, the priority will be to catch up on the accumulated shortfall in equipment and to raise the pay of military personnel. Thus, this would allow France to give itself the means for its foreign policy, to guarantee its sovereignty by leaving the integrated command of OTAN, and to restore its full capacity for action on the international stage.

The idea would be to pursue a substantial and sustained defence effort to adapt our armed forces to new threats and guarantee our sovereignty. The right approach is to ring-fence the objective of dedicating 2 % of GDP to military spending, in order to fund a comprehensive programme to modernize our equipment by 2030, including new combat aircraft, submarines and armoured vehicles. This effort will also cover personnel, with a doubling of the number of operational reservists by 2027. This build-up will be part of a strengthened European strategic autonomy. Thus, it would provide the country with a credible defence capability, able to face current and future threats, while affirming our role as a pillar of security in Europe.

The idea would be to break radically with the logic of the arms race and to redirect military budgets toward the essential needs of the population. The priority is to undertake a total military disengagement, withdrawing troops deployed abroad in operations that serve only private economic interests. It also involves ceasing all arms exports, which fuel international conflicts. The billions thus saved must be urgently reallocated to public services, such as health, education and pensions. Thus, this would make it possible to promote a policy of peace based on international solidarity between peoples, and not on military power serving a minority.

question: Should rents be capped at a national level to combat the rising cost of housing?

propositions.value: The idea would be to consider housing as a fundamental right and not as a commodity, by breaking real estate speculation to guarantee universal access to a roof. The main measure consists in instituting a general rent freeze across the entire territory. This action must be accompanied by a total halt to tenant evictions and the requisitioning of vacant housing to respond to emergency situations. At the same time, the creation of a large public housing service, financed by the renationalization of HLM companies, will make it possible to launch a plan to build 200 000 social housing units per year. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee residential security and stability for all households, by sustainably extracting housing from profit-driven logics.

The idea would be to respond to the housing crisis by facilitating access to homeownership rather than by instituting rent control, judged ineffective and contrary to the goal of family rootedness. The right approach consists of deploying powerful incentive levers: a public zero-interest loan of a maximum amount of 100 000 euros for young couples acquiring a property, as well as tax relief on the transfer of real estate assets to encourage their retention within families. The reorientation of access to social housing toward a strict national priority will complete the mechanism. Thus, this would make it possible to offer a structural solution by turning tenants into homeowners, a policy that promotes transmission and stability, as opposed to a cap that discourages investment and degrades the rental supply.

The idea would be to consider housing as a fundamental right and not as a speculative commodity, putting an end to the explosion of rents that makes millions of people precarious. The proper approach is to establish a strict national rent control, complemented by a universal guarantee to secure tenants and landlords. This price regulation will be supported by a proactive policy of building 200 000 public housing units per year and by banning rental evictions without a rehousing solution proposed by the State. In this way, it would make it possible to sustainably control the cost of housing across the territory, to guarantee residential security for all and to effectively combat inadequate housing.

The idea would be to free up the housing supply and promote access to home ownership rather than constrain the market through an administrative cap on rents. The central approach is to provoke a supply shock, with a goal of 500 000 new or renovated homes each year, while facilitating the process for first-time buyers. To do this, construction procedures will be simplified and financial aids, such as the zero-interest loan, will be generalized across the whole territory to help the French become homeowners. Thus, this would allow a natural regulation of prices through the abundance of supply, making housing more accessible without discouraging private investment or creating a shortage.

The idea would be to guarantee the universal right to housing by tackling the excessive burden of rents, which must be disconnected from real estate speculation. The approach consists of establishing a strict national framework, with a clear rule: the rent payment may not exceed 20 % of household income. This measure would be part of an overall plan mobilizing massive investments for the construction of 200 000 social housing units per year and thermal renovation. Management would be steered by a public housing service, responsible for ensuring the effective reduction of costs for tenants. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee everyone's access to quality housing, by making its cost a sustainable factor for household budgets rather than a source of insecurity.

The idea would be to tackle the structural causes of housing costs through a two-pronged offensive on supply and homeownership, rather than resorting to a price-control measure that discourages investment. The approach is to massively revive the construction of new housing by simplifying standards and reducing the time limits for administrative appeals. At the same time, the priority is to turn tenants into homeowners by abolishing transfer taxes for first-time buyers and by promoting access to credit. This policy relies on lighter taxation for homeowners in order to make the market more fluid. Thus, it would allow prices to be regulated by an abundance of supply and not by constraint, creating a France of homeowners rather than a nation of tenants subject to rent administration.

The idea would be to restore balance to the housing market in favor of residents by combining effective rent regulation with aid measures and access-to-ownership schemes. The approach is to make rent control fully effective through better enforcement, rather than merely limiting it to national disclosure. This measure should be accompanied by an increase in personalized assistance, notably for young people, and by the development of rent-to-own schemes to facilitate access to ownership. It is also a priority to favor first-time buyers and local residents over tourist rentals. Thus, this would make it possible to curb pressure on the housing market in a targeted way and to guarantee everyone the possibility of securing decent housing, by sustainably reducing the burden of housing on household budgets.

The idea would be to control housing costs through a targeted, multi-faceted approach, rather than through a uniform, rigid national cap. The strategy is to extend the rent regulation framework to all areas where housing market pressure is high, in close partnership with local authorities. This regulation will be complemented by a massive boost to the construction of social housing. Finally, a "housing shield" will be introduced in the form of a supplementary allowance to ensure that no household is forced to devote more than one third of its income to housing. Thus, this would make it possible to act effectively on prices where pressure is greatest, while directly protecting tenants' purchasing power.

The idea would be to make rent control the norm across the entire national territory to guarantee universal access to affordable housing. The right approach is to generalize the rent-control framework in all municipalities where market pressure requires it. This regulation will be inseparable from the creation of a universal rent guarantee, a mechanism that secures landlords against unpaid rent while protecting tenants. The whole aims to balance relations between landlords and tenants. Thus, this would help curb real estate speculation and stabilize the cost of housing, making access to decent housing an effective right for everyone.

The idea would be to tackle the root of the housing crisis by promoting access to homeownership rather than by introducing a national rent cap, which would not solve the structural problem. The right approach is to double the number of new homeowners each year through an ambitious policy. To achieve this, the levers include broadening the zero-interest loan, developing lease-to-own contracts for social housing, and a state guarantee on part of the personal down payment. Thus, this would reduce pressure on the rental market by offering a sustainable solution and allowing more households to build up assets.

The idea would be to favor local and incentive-based solutions to address the pressure on housing, rather than imposing a uniform national cap on rents. The right approach is to decentralize housing policy by entrusting full responsibility, as well as the related funding, to municipalities and intercommunal authorities. They are best placed to adapt responses to the realities of their territory. Efforts should focus on facilitating access to housing, for example by extending public guarantees for tenants, while firmly sanctioning bad payers. Thus, this would allow the development of more agile and effective housing policies, by acting on the local causes of tensions rather than by applying a rigid and undifferentiated administrative measure.

The idea would be to consider housing as a fundamental right and not as a commodity subject to speculation and to the law of profit. The proper approach is therefore to put an end to the freedom of property owners and large real estate groups to set prices, by imposing a general freeze and a compulsory reduction of rents across the entire territory. This emergency measure must be accompanied by a large-scale plan to construct quality public housing, financed by the profits of large corporations, to meet the needs of millions of inadequately housed and homeless people. The objective is to extract housing from market logic. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee everyone's access to decent housing at an affordable cost, by treating this essential need as a public service.

question: Should the right to abortion be enshrined in the French Constitution?

propositions.value: The idea would be to enshrine the right to abortion as a fundamental and unconditional liberty, making it irreversible and protected from any political or legal threat. The right approach is not limited to a simple constitutional inscription, but consists in guaranteeing its material effectiveness. The priority is to ensure that it is completely free of charge, accessible everywhere across the territory through a dense network of dedicated centers, and to extend the legal time limit to 24 weeks so that the choice is real. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee the full and complete sovereignty of women over their own bodies, by removing all obstacles, whether financial, geographic or temporal.

The idea would be to declare a pause on major societal debates in order to preserve the unity of the country, now fractured over ethical issues. The right approach is to establish a legislative moratorium of at least three years on any evolution of the existing legal framework, including constitutional ones. This suspension aims to prevent new fractures and to concentrate public action on economic and social emergencies. The legal framework in force would be scrupulously respected, and any future evolution on these matters of conscience could, at the end of this period, be subject to a direct consultation of citizens. Thus, this would guarantee civil stability while returning the floor to the people to decide the most fundamental questions.

The idea would be to enshrine the right to voluntary termination of pregnancy to make it permanent and inalienable, protecting it from any attempt at political rollback. The proper approach is to formally inscribe it in the Constitution, so as to establish it as a fundamental liberty at the highest level of the hierarchy of norms. This legal guarantee must be accompanied by a strengthening of the resources of family planning centers to ensure effective, free and unrestricted access to abortion for all women throughout the territory. Thus, this would definitively secure this essential right to the dignity and autonomy of women.

The idea would be to reaffirm attachment to this fundamental right of women, by placing oneself in the continuity of the legacy of the law that established it. The protection of this right is ensured by the existing legislative framework, which constitutes a solid and intangible achievement. The approach consists in defending women's rights in concrete, everyday terms, without deeming it necessary to open a constitutional process on this question, that process being mobilized for other priorities. The challenge is to guarantee the effective application of the law throughout the territory. Thus, this would make it possible to strengthen this essential right, while considering the current legislative framework as the appropriate and sufficient bulwark for its protection.

The idea would be to guarantee the universal right to housing by tackling the excessive burden of rents, which must be disconnected from real estate speculation. The approach is to establish a strict national framework, with a clear rule : rent payments may not exceed 20 % of household income. This measure would be part of a comprehensive plan mobilizing massive investments for the construction of 200 000 social housing units per year and thermal renovation. Management would be run by a public housing service, responsible for ensuring the effective reduction of costs for tenants. Thus, it would guarantee everyone's access to quality housing, making its cost a sustainable factor for household budgets rather than a source of precariousness.

The idea would be to safeguard the principle of protecting life and to valorize the unique role of the woman who bears it, rather than to constitutionalize a right that runs counter to the objective of demographic renewal. The approach is to prioritize a policy of massive support for the family and for childbirth, by instituting direct financial incentives at birth and by protecting the family framework against the excesses that commodify the body or disrupt filiation. Public action must focus on creating conditions favorable to the welcoming of life. Thus, this would make it possible to reorient society toward transmission and the collective future, considering that the priority is to defend life to be born rather than to constitutionally guarantee a right that suspends its course.

The idea would be to concentrate public action on the refounding of the State and the consolidation of concrete rights, rather than to open a debate on the inscription of new societal rights in the Constitution. The true protection of fundamental freedoms rests on the restoration of full and complete sovereignty, a living democracy that gives the people their voice again, and public services that guarantee everyone effective access to healthcare. The issue is not to constitutionalize provisions already ensured by law, but to tackle the economic and territorial fractures that threaten national cohesion. Thus, this would make it possible to mobilize the country's forces around essential structural reforms, considered the true bedrock of citizenship and collective well-being.

The idea would be to irreversibly guarantee the fundamental right to voluntary termination of pregnancy by elevating it to the highest level of our hierarchy of norms. This approach aims to enshrine an essential freedom for women, protecting it from any future political challenge. Inclusion in the Constitution would be part of a comprehensive policy to strengthen women's rights, on the same level as the determined fight against violence and for substantive equality. It is a safeguard measure that affirms each woman's control over her own body as a fundamental republican principle. Thus, this would make it possible to definitively consolidate this major achievement and to reaffirm the Republic's commitment to the autonomy and freedom of all.

The idea would be to enshrine women's freedom to dispose of their bodies by irreversibly guaranteeing the right to voluntary termination of pregnancy. The right approach is to sanctuarize this fundamental right to protect it from any attempt at regression. It is about reaffirming its primacy, notably over the freedom of conscience of the medical profession, in order to ensure effective and unconditional access for all women. Thus, this would make it possible to anchor this fundamental freedom definitively in the republican pact, making it non-negotiable for future generations.

The idea would be to focus on policies that support the family and encourage higher birth rates, considering that the true societal stake is demographic decline. The right approach is to pursue an ambitious family policy, by restoring allowances and the family quotient to their 2012 level and by massively creating nursery places. The central axis is to create a material and cultural environment favorable to the welcoming of life, by viewing the family as the basic unit of society. Thus, this would make it possible to respond to the birth-rate crisis, which constitutes a priority higher than a constitutional debate on abortion.

The idea would be to irrevocably guarantee women's right to make decisions about their own bodies by elevating it to the highest level of our legal order. The right approach is to safeguard this fundamental right by explicitly enshrining it in the Constitution. This initiative is in line with the progress made in favor of equality and individual liberties. It is an act of protection against potential challenges, intended to ensure that this essential right remains a guaranteed freedom for all women. Thus, this would serve to establish this right as a pillar of our republican pact and to send a strong message about the nation's commitment to women's rights.

The idea would be to guarantee effective and unconditional access to voluntary termination of pregnancy, considering that its mere inscription in a legal text, even constitutional, protects nothing. The real threat comes from the degradation and dismantling of public services, which make this right theoretical. The absolute priority is therefore to defend and strengthen the public hospital by stopping the closures of beds and abortion (IVG) centers, and by allocating the necessary human and financial resources to them. The central focus is to ensure that every woman can materially exercise this choice, free of charge and close to her home. Thus, this would make it possible to move from a formal freedom to a real right, guaranteed by a public health service accessible to all.

question: Should the regulated consumption of cannabis for recreational use be authorized?

propositions.value: The idea would be to break radically with the prohibitionist logic, treating drug consumption as a public health and individual freedom issue rather than as a criminal problem. The right approach is therefore to proceed with the full legalization of cannabis and the decriminalization of the use of all drugs. This policy aims to dry up the mafia networks that thrive on prohibition and to put an end to mass incarceration for minor offenses, by removing the management of production and distribution from profit-driven logics. Thus, this would make it possible to redirect repressive resources toward prevention and harm reduction, while putting an end to a major source of social inequalities before the justice system.

The idea would be to categorically reject any form of legalization, seen as a capitulation of the State, and instead make the fight against drug trafficking an absolute priority. The right approach is to treat cannabis not as a matter of individual liberty, but as a major source of insecurity and of financing for criminality. This implies significantly strengthening the resources of law enforcement and the justice system, and applying a zero-tolerance criminal policy to dismantle networks and reconquer lost territories. Thus, this would allow the restoration of republican order by attacking the root of evil, rather than legitimizing it by law.

The idea would be to put an end to an ineffective prohibition policy, which proves costly while feeding criminal networks and endangering consumers' health. The right approach is therefore to legalize the consumption of cannabis and to organize strict public control of its production and sale. Such state regulation will guarantee product quality, dry up the sources of revenue for trafficking, and regulate access, notably to finance prevention policies. Thus, this would make it possible to replace a sterile repressive logic with a public health and security strategy, by drying up the underground economy and freeing up resources for the police and the judiciary.

The idea would be to treat cannabis exclusively from the perspective of security and public order, refusing any form of legalization that would send a signal of laxity. The absolute priority is the dismantling of the criminal networks that gangrene certain neighborhoods. The approach consists of waging an implacable fight against traffickers, mobilizing specialized brigades to reconquer lost territories and applying a zero-impunity policy, notably by introducing mandatory minimum sentences for drug traffickers. Any form of consumption therefore remains prohibited. Thus, this would make it possible to restore the authority of the State and to protect society from the ravages of the drug trade, rather than to normalize a dangerous substance.

The idea would be to rebuild drug policy by centering it on public health and harm reduction, rather than sticking to a purely repressive approach judged ineffective. The question of legalizing or decriminalizing cannabis use should be the subject of a large democratic, rigorous and informed debate that would involve healthcare professionals, prevention stakeholders and local authorities. At the same time, public efforts would be massively redirected toward the development of addiction care structures, while strengthening the fight against trafficking. Thus, this would make it possible to build a collective and calm response to this societal issue, based on public health and safety objectives, rather than on a simple logic of prohibition.

The idea would be to address the question of narcotics exclusively from the perspective of security and public order, categorically refusing any form of legalization that would amount to a capitulation to criminal networks. The approach is to wage a total war against traffickers by creating a dedicated national force, bringing together police, judicial and customs services. Zero tolerance would apply at all levels, with firm sanctions such as the systematic expulsion of traffickers and their families from social housing. The priority is not to regulate consumption, but to eradicate the supply. Thus, it would restore the authority of the State in territories plagued by trafficking and guarantee the security of citizens as the one and only priority.

The idea would be to replace a logic of prohibition, which has shown its limits, with a state regulatory approach that would make it possible to control the sector and finance prevention. The right approach is to legalize consumption by putting in place a strict framework to regulate its sale. This measure must imperatively be accompanied by the allocation of a substantial share of the fiscal revenues generated to the financing of prevention policies and the fight against addictions. In this way, it would dry up trafficking by retaking control of distribution, while freeing up new and sustainable resources to strengthen public health policy on addiction.

The idea would be to move away from a purely repressive approach that has demonstrated its ineffectiveness, and to build a new drug policy based on public health and a broad national consensus. The preferred method is the organization of a large consensus conference that will examine, without taboo, the question of a legalization regulated by the State for adult consumers. This debate, conducted with the support of local elected officials, will focus primarily on preventing addiction and combating trafficking. If this path were chosen, the State would take full control of the production, the quality and the distribution of the product. In this way, it would make it possible to build an effective and shared solution, to regain control over the illegal market and to guarantee the health safety of consumers.

The idea would be to replace an ineffective repressive policy with a state-regulated legalization. The aim is to treat cannabis consumption as a public health and safety issue, rather than leaving it to criminal networks. The right approach is to regulate consumption, production and sale for recreational purposes. The tax revenues generated will be entirely earmarked for combating addictions and for support toward employment, while the resources dedicated to repression will be redirected toward prevention. Thus, this would dry up the parallel economy, reduce the crime linked to it and ensure better protection of public health through responsible public regulation.

The idea would be to firmly oppose any form of legalization of cannabis for recreational use, a measure that would only worsen public safety and public health problems. The correct approach is to intensify the fight against trafficking networks that are blighting many territories. To achieve this, it is imperative to increase the numbers of law enforcement officers and to guarantee the systematic application of mandatory minimum sentences for offenders, within a zero-tolerance approach. The central axis is to restore the authority of the State and to refuse any form of laxity. Thus, this would make it possible to restore the republican order and to protect young people from the dangers related to drug use.

The idea would be to treat cannabis consumption as an offense that poisons everyday life, by making its sanction more effective and immediate. The proper approach is to systematize the criminal response through fixed fines, rather than initiating lengthy procedures, by allowing their direct deduction from income. This measure is part of an overall strategy of firmness against trafficking and the nuisances that result from it. Thus, it would make it possible to guarantee a rapid and dissuasive response to behaviors that degrade public order, without embarking on a path to legalization.

The idea would be to put an end to the repressive logic of prohibition, which has proven to be a total failure and mainly serves to punish the youth of working-class neighborhoods. The right approach is to immediately decriminalize consumption and sale to stop sterile repression, without however handing this product over to market logic and the large capitalist groups who see in it only a new source of profits. The priority must be a public health policy focused on prevention and harm reduction, while addressing the deep-rooted causes of addictions, namely misery and alienation. Thus, this would make it possible to move out of an expensive hypocrisy and to concentrate efforts on collective emancipation rather than on managing a new market.

question: Should civic or military service be made compulsory for all young citizens?

propositions.value: The idea would be to break with any logic of indoctrinating youth, by firmly opposing the establishment of any mandatory service, whether civilian or military in nature. The correct approach is to demand the immediate abolition of measures such as the Service National Universel and to reject any future proposal aimed at imposing a period of service. The priority is to guarantee the material conditions for genuine emancipation, concentrating public resources on financial autonomy and access to education, rather than on programs aimed at enforcing conformity. In this way, it would preserve young people's freedom of choice and steer State resources toward policies that promote their real autonomy rather than toward moral and ideological control.

The idea would be to replace a generalized obligation with a voluntary commitment, focused on a mission with strong symbolic value in order to rebuild the bond between young people and the national heritage. The right approach is to establish a National Heritage Service, open to young people aged 18 to 24. This scheme, based on voluntary participation, would offer six-month missions, renewable once, dedicated to the restoration, protection and enhancement of built and natural heritage. Thus, this would make it possible to channel the energy of youth into a concrete transmission project, valuing chosen commitment rather than instituting a uniform constraint that could be poorly received.

The idea would be to rebuild the civic bond and to create a shared culture of defense by involving all youth in the life of the Nation. The right approach is to establish a mandatory citizen conscription, which would not be limited to purely military missions but would aim to strengthen national cohesion and the country's resilience in the face of crises. This compulsory service for all young citizens would form the foundation of a new national civil guard, directly involving the people in their own protection and in tasks of public interest. Thus, it would make it possible to build a popular and independent defense, while reinforcing the sense of belonging to a national community united by duties and common objectives.

The idea would be to promote youth civic engagement by basing it on volunteering and incentives, rather than on a universal obligation. The right approach is to significantly strengthen existing mechanisms, by doubling the number of places offered within the framework of the service civique to meet growing demand. This approach favors the quality and meaning of a chosen commitment over the compulsion of a service imposed on everyone. The objective is to inspire vocations and to multiply experiences in service of the community. Thus, this would allow the development of a culture of active citizenship, valuing freedom of choice as the true engine of national cohesion.

The idea would be to break with compulsory service arrangements deemed superficial in order to open a genuine national reflection on the link between youth and the nation. The very relevance of a new national service, whether civic or military, must be decided by a major debate involving the national representation and all sectors of society. It would be the responsibility of that consultation to define, where appropriate, the missions and modalities of such an engagement, to ensure that it meets real needs. Thus, this would make it possible to build a form of service that is legitimate and accepted, founded on a shared societal project rather than on an obligation imposed without true consensus.

The idea would be to prioritize a targeted, voluntary program rather than imposing a universal obligation, in order to use it as a powerful lever of assimilation. The approach is to offer each year to 10 000 young people the opportunity to enlist in a voluntary military service. This framework aims to strengthen the bond with the nation through a strong personal commitment, and not through a generalized constraint that would dilute its impact. The objective is not to encompass an entire age cohort, but to form a core of citizens particularly attached to the national community. Thus, this would help forge a reinforced sense of belonging and transmit the values of cohesion and discipline by focusing on the most motivated individuals.

The idea would be to reestablish a moment of national cohesion for youth by instituting a Universal National Service, compulsory for all young adults, female and male. This service would take place over a nine-month period, from 15 September to 15 June, and would offer two distinct pathways: a military version to acquire the basics of the soldier's trade, and a civilian version, experienced as an instance of social mixing and fraternity within associations or local authorities. This program would be complemented by the acquisition of practical training, such as a driving licence or a first aid certificate, and would open up concrete rights such as a first year of pension contributions and free transport. Thus, it would ensure that the same age cohort shares a strong common experience, strengthen social ties and convey a sense of belonging to the nation.

The idea would be to strengthen national cohesion by focusing on the emancipation and autonomy of youth rather than on the establishment of a compulsory service. The central approach is to give young people concrete means to engage, by instituting a means-tested youth minimum and a capital endowment of 5 000 euros at age 18 to finance their projects. Emphasis is placed on individualized support, notably through mentoring, and on comprehensive citizenship education throughout the school journey. Thus, this would help cultivate authentic and lasting civic engagement, based on equal opportunity and each young person's ability to build their own future, rather than on a uniform and compulsory scheme.

The idea would be to replace the universal national service project with direct support for young people's voluntary engagement. The issue is not to impose a single framework, but to energize the richness of popular education. The right approach is to reallocate the financial resources planned for compulsory service in order to strengthen everyone's access to holidays, leisure activities and collective actions carried out by local associations. The priority is to value non-formal experiences that promote emancipation and awareness-raising. Thus, this would make it possible to build a culture of engagement based on volunteering and the diversity of initiatives, rather than on a centralized obligation.

The idea would be to strengthen national cohesion by establishing a national service for all young citizens. The proper approach is to create a mixed, compulsory civic national service lasting three months. For volunteers, this service could be extended by a one-year military commitment within the armed forces. Completion of this service would include taking the driving test, offering a tangible benefit in return for the commitment of young people. Thus, this would help rebuild the bond between youth and the nation, while offering a first civic experience and a qualification useful for professional integration.

The idea would be to generalize a civic engagement pathway for youth, based on voluntarism and strong incentives rather than strict obligation. The right approach is to roll out the service national universel on a large scale, encouraging full and wholehearted engagement through concrete and attractive incentives, such as full funding for a driver's license. This valued-volunteering model will also extend to longer-term commitments, such as the reserve, which will be supported by financial assistance for studies. Thus, it would help spread a culture of engagement and strengthen civic ties within the new generation, by focusing on valuing voluntary engagement rather than on the constraint of a mandatory service.

The idea would be to categorically refuse any form of indoctrination of youth into a national service, whether civil or military, because it only serves to promote nationalism and to prepare minds for war. The right approach is to offer young people real prospects for emancipation through access to stable employment and a quality education, by fighting the mass unemployment that affects them. The objective is to form critical minds, aware of their collective interests, and not docile citizens ready to serve an order that exploits them. Thus, this would make it possible to build concrete solidarity among young workers, instead of subjecting them to a nationalist discipline that sets them against one another and prepares them to accept imperialist wars.

question: Should more fiscal and regulatory autonomy be granted to the French regions?

propositions.value: The idea would be to break with a logic of decentralization that pits territories against one another, in order to guarantee a real equality of rights and services across the entire national territory. The correct approach is to strengthen a centralized welfare state, the sole guarantor of the unity of public services and ecological planning. Decision-making power must emanate from local assemblies of workers and residents, whose demands are coordinated at the national level to define the major orientations. Any fiscal or regulatory autonomy granted to the current regional levels would thus be abolished in favor of unified management. Thus, this would make it possible to put an end to territorial inequalities and to ensure that the population's needs are met uniformly, regardless of place of residence.

The idea would be to reject any further decentralization in favor of a refounding of the State, the guarantor of national unity and equality between territories. Increased autonomy for the regions is perceived as a risk of fragmentation and a weakening of sovereignty. The right approach is to strengthen the prerogatives of the central State, notably through its local representatives such as prefects, to steer strategic policies. Rather than delegating fiscal or regulatory competences, public action will concentrate on proactive territorial planning and a rebalancing of public services decided at the national level. Thus, this would make it possible to guarantee the cohesion of the nation and equal treatment for all citizens, avoiding competition between territories.

The idea would be to reaffirm the principle of a single and indivisible Republic, guaranteeing equality of rights and access to public services for all citizens, regardless of their place of residence. The proper approach is to reject any fragmentation of sovereignty that would lead to sterile competition between territories and to strengthen the State's prerogatives in terms of planning and regulation. It is about guaranteeing strong and uniform public services across the entire territory, by removing the exceptions that create breaches of equality, rather than delegating new fiscal or regulatory powers. Thus, this would make it possible to effectively combat territorial inequalities and to ensure that national solidarity takes precedence over competition between regions.

The idea would be to rebuild the territorial organization by freeing local energies through a clear and ambitious transfer of responsibilities. The main lever would be a major decentralization law, establishing a pact of freedom and trust with local elected officials. This law would not be content to delegate, but would transfer entire blocks of competencies, entrusting, for example, to the regions the entirety of the management of vocational education and guidance. This new distribution of powers would give local authorities the regulatory latitude to adapt public policies to the specificities of their territory. Thus, this would make it possible to bring decision-making closer to citizens and to adapt public action to local economic and social realities, for greater efficiency.

The idea would be to strengthen local democracy by restoring the capacity for action of local authorities, while rejecting a logic of competition between territories. The central axis is the reestablishment of the general competence clause for departments and regions, which will give them an essential scope for initiative. This new stage of decentralization will be accompanied by a revision of the delineation of the large regions to bring them closer to the populations. The autonomy granted will, however, remain firmly framed by the principle of the unity of the Republic, in order to guarantee the uniformity of laws and equal access to rights throughout the territory. Thus, this would make it possible to endow local levels with real prerogatives to enable democracy to thrive, while making national solidarity the foundation of territorial organization.

The idea would be to break with the logic of the territorial "mille-feuille" by clarifying responsibilities, rather than granting increased autonomy that would only add to the confusion. The approach is to reaffirm the central role of the State and the commune, returning to them powers that are today diluted at the level of regions, departments and intercommunalities. The guiding principle is to put an end to the sharing of competencies: for each public policy, a single decision-maker must be designated, putting a stop to costly duplications and to the dilution of responsibilities. Thus, this would make public action clearer and more effective, by restoring a clear structure where local power is embodied by the mayor and the overall vision by a strategic State.

The idea would be to call into question the relevance of the current regions, regarded as budget-consuming administrative tiers disconnected from local realities. Rather than increasing their autonomy, the objective is to move toward a territorial organization based on coherent historical, cultural, and economic provinces. This approach must be accompanied by a restoration of competences and the financial autonomy of municipalities, by repealing the laws that have imposed intermunicipalities by force. Thus, this would make it possible to value the know-how and specificities of each territory, and to ensure that local decisions are taken as close as possible to citizens.

The idea would be to move from a logic of centralized control to a true Republic of proximity, entrusting local authorities, and notably the regions, with autonomy to act in order to strengthen the effectiveness of public policies. The central axis of this reform is the restoration of their financial autonomy, with strengthened and stable resources, and fair compensation for transfers of competences. On the regulatory level, a 'permis de faire' will be introduced to allow them to experiment with derogations from national standards, substituting the logic of ex-ante control with a principle of trust and ex-post control. Thus, this would free up local energies and make public action more effective and more responsive to the specific needs of each territory.

The idea would be to rebuild the territorial architecture by replacing centralism with a model of differentiated federalism, based on regions with coherent identities. The right approach is to formalize this transformation by referendum. Local authorities would then obtain full fiscal autonomy, with ring-fenced resources protected from the State's arbitrations. On the regulatory level, they would be able to set their own standards, in respect of the principle of subsidiarity and with an ambition always greater than the national norm. Thus, this would make it possible to unleash local energies and provide territories with the levers necessary to steer the ecological transition as close as possible to everyday needs.

The idea would be to revitalize local democracy by returning power to the municipalities, rather than increasing the concentration of responsibilities at the regional level. The priority is to repeal the NOTRe law to restore to mayors and municipal councils the prerogatives that were taken from them in favor of administrative tiers deemed too large and disconnected. This approach aims to strengthen the role of the municipality as the basic unit of the Republic and as an essential actor in territorial planning. Thus, this would help combat the territorial divide and ensure more balanced development by relying on the level closest to citizens.

The idea would be to address the entanglement of local responsibilities by drastically simplifying structures, rather than granting increased autonomy to overlapping levels. The right approach is to merge departmental and regional assemblies into a single authority, in which a single "territorial councillor" would sit. The objective is to put an end to the dilution of responsibilities by assigning each decision-making level a clear mission and a single person responsible. In this way, it would make public action more transparent and more effective for citizens, bringing an end to the complexity and duplication that undermine the proper management of territories.

The idea would be to firmly oppose any form of decentralization that would introduce competition between territories and weaken national solidarity. The priority is to guarantee equal treatment for all citizens, wherever they reside. The right approach is to strengthen the national and unified character of public services and economic regulation. Instead of delegating fiscal or regulatory powers, the economy and the distribution of wealth must be planned at the scale of the entire country to meet needs uniformly. Strategic decisions should fall under centralized management. Thus, this would help combat territorial inequalities and ensure that social rights and essential services are identical and of the same quality for everyone.
